stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on texturing the volcanic mountain area of the overworld, collaborating with live feedback from chat and team member Biobak. He also discussed the results of a recent beta test for Course 4, the creation of a public progress tracker, and his personal philosophies on game design and his work as a YouTuber.

development_findings.summary: The first beta test for Course 4 is complete. While mostly positive, it revealed a soft-locking bug and that the 'plane mission sucks'.
The game's sound engine has been completely remade, allowing for the addition of new sound effects like propeller and windmill sounds to enhance immersion.
development_findings.quote: The little propeller sound makes it feel so much more alive to me.

development_findings.summary: In response to constant questions about the release date, Kaze created and shared a public progress tracker spreadsheet detailing the completion percentage of each level and game component.
During the overworld design, Kaze decided to cap the volcanic cliffs with grass instead of just rock, prioritizing a 'friendly' aesthetic suitable for the game over geological realism.
development_findings.quote: It's going to look a lot more friendly, which is important for Yoshi's Islands.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is blocked by a lighting bug in the Fast64 tool and is waiting for the tool's developers to issue a fix.
Kaze explains that smooth texture transitions on the terrain are achieved using transparent decals with a 'Red X Alpha' that fades in.
The game is being developed to run on real N64 hardware, and Kaze plans to fix crashes that occur on the Everdrive flash cart.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes making YouTube videos, which he considers 'nonsense' that takes time away from game development, but continues because it is financially necessary.
context_findings.quote: Do I like making videos? No, I hate making videos. But it's good money.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that major ethical responsibilities should be handled at a legal/systemic level rather than being pushed onto individuals, as individual actions have little impact compared to the personal burden.
context_findings.quote: I think morality and ethics like that should be part of law because as an individual you are too depersonalized from that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that constantly advancing hardware is detrimental and that sticking with a single console generation for longer would lead to more, better, and cheaper games.
context_findings.quote: Can we just stop and just like explore one hardware? We're gonna get better games, we're gonna get cheaper games, I'm gonna get more games.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of a large, profitable industry selling bootleg cartridges of his hacks and worries about the potential legal repercussions from Nintendo, despite having no involvement.
context_findings.quote: I bet my ROMX probably made over a million dollars at this point through rebroad cartridges. The problem is I'm a little scared that Nintendo is going to murder me for that, but I have nothing to do with it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze defines a good game as a 'series of interesting choices' and criticizes popular games like Harvest Moon and Bully as being 'just chores'.

biobak.summary: Biobak is collaborating with Kaze on a solution for the 'plane mission' in Course 4, which was poorly received in its first beta test.
Kaze refers to Biobak as the 'rock expert' and relies on his live feedback while texturing the volcanic mountain in the overworld.
Kaze clarifies that Biobak's role is primarily graphical updates, though he also contributes minor gameplay changes that are easy to implement.
biobak.quote: Biobak rework is just him updating the graphics. That's like 90% of what he does. He does make some gameplay changes, but they are all very simple to accommodate.

biobak.summary: Kaze notes that even 'finished' levels like Course 3 might be reworked again if Biobak decides he wants to make further changes.

badub.summary: Kaze has started importing Badub's custom sound effects into the game's newly remade sound engine.
Badub composed the new overworld theme, which now incorporates the game's main musical theme.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentioned telling 'Eiza' (likely Zeina) that he should create a B3313-style hack, which would be easy to make.

key_stories.title: Texturing the Volcanic Mountain
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to find the right look for the overworld's volcanic mountain. After trying several textures and getting live feedback from Biobak, he decided to prioritize a 'friendly' aesthetic suitable for a Yoshi's Island game over pure realism, opting to cap the cliffs with grass.
key_stories.challenge: The initial textures and geometry for the overworld's volcanic mountain looked 'horrid' and lacked a clear artistic direction that fit the game.
key_stories.process: Kaze iterated through multiple rock textures live on stream, soliciting feedback from the chat and artist Biobak. He debated realism versus the Mario art style and experimented with different visual concepts like horizontal stripes before arriving at the decision to add grass to soften the appearance.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze established a clear design plan: the mountain will have distinct volcanic and non-volcanic sides, and the cliffs will be topped with grass to make them appear friendly and non-climbable, aligning with the game's overall aesthetic.
key_stories.key_quote: It's going to look a lot more friendly, which is important for Yoshi's Islands.

key_stories.title: The Release Date Question
key_stories.summary: To combat the constant, annoying questions about a release date, Kaze created a public progress tracker. This spreadsheet shows the completion percentage of each level, satisfying community curiosity about the game's status while avoiding the pressure of a fixed deadline.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze was getting frustrated by the constant, repetitive questions from the community about the game's release date.
key_stories.process: Instead of simply ignoring the questions or expressing frustration, Kaze decided to create a tool to proactively address the community's underlying interest in the game's progress. He built a detailed spreadsheet breaking down the completion percentage of all major components.
key_stories.outcome: He created a public progress tracker spreadsheet that he can share whenever asked. This satisfies the community's curiosity about the game's status while reinforcing his 'it's done when it's done' policy without having to repeat himself.
key_stories.key_quote: If you guys really want, I did this yesterday. You can see how far along the game is.
